title.text: A COMPUTATIONAL VIEW OF THE COGNITIVE SEMANTICS OF SPATIAL PREPOSITIONS*

abstractContent.text: This paper outlines the linguistic semantic commitments underlying an application which automatically constructs depictions of verbal spatial descriptions.

Our approach draws on the ideational view of linguistic semantics developed by Ronald Langacker in his theory of Cognitive Grammar, and the conceptual representation of physical objects from the two-level semantics of Bierwisch and Lang.
In particular the dimensions of the process of conventwnal imagery are used as a metric for the design of our own conceptual representation.

introductionContent.text: An increased interest in ttle semantics of spatial language has accompanied the recent rise in popularity of cognitive linguistics (see), yet computational approaches are thin on the ground.

This can in part be accounted for by the rather descriptive and unformalized nature of the theories developed, but is more likely due to the adoption of an ideational view of linguistic meaning which, it seems, is an anathema to computational linguists.
In this paper we take a serious, if informal, look at Ronald Langacker's theory of Cognitive Grammar,,, more specifically its commitment to conceptualization and the use of conventional imagery.

The first section of this paper introduces the semantics of projective prepositions (eg. "in front of", "behind", "left of", "right of"), illustrating that these seemingly simple predicates are suprisingly complex and ambiguous.
